SpNote.note:
A note about notes ----------------
This is a note outlining good practice in note writing for heterodyne MSB. PLEASE replace this note with your own note or delete altogether BEFORE submitting the MSB.
Things to include in your notes -------------------------------
* Calibration details
1) Overall observing strategy for your science program. A paragraph conveying the general ideas behind your science program is useful for the observer (who may not be an expert in your field) and the TSS. (Check "show to the Observer").
2) Details of calibration observations. Spell out any specific calibrations you require in the note which is selected as "show-to-observer". Example instructions might include:
"Short sample on a nearby spectral line standard with a good CO(3-2) line e.g. OMC1".
and/or
"Short sample on a point-like planet (e.g. Uranus), with same backend set up as science target."
In short, you'll at least want something to check back-end setup and receiver performance (e.g. a spectral line standard). Optional is an efficiency measurement on a planet to check the convertion of the measured antenna temperature to an astrophysical brightness temperature. However, isolated efficiency observations scatter considerably and using a suitable average of archived values may be preferential.
3) If you want more specific standard or calibration measurement you should make a separate MSBs with these measurements or include them as extra observation in your MSBs. Calibration observations should be flagged as 'calibration' on their title page to prevent unnecessary repeats.
SpNote.title: Please read

SpNote.note:
Calibration: ---------
Presently there is no easy way to insert calibration observation MSBs. The reason is that there are many considerations that go into the choice of what calibators to use and how to do the calibration observations. Moreover whether the observation can be beam-switched or needs to be position-switched, as well as the magnitude and direction of the switch, all depend on the frequency and calibrator itself. Without any specific instructions in the science program the operators will insert calibrations to the best of their ability, but you are strongly urged to submit the following information to ensure that the calibration will match your expectations:
1) _X_ A precise calibration is not needed. It is sufficient to ensure that the telescope and receiver work within spec. ___ A precise calibration is important. Please use program time to ensure a calibration as accurate as possible (note that this may increase the overhead e.g. if the program allows for short MSBs on different nights).
2) _X_ The calibration can be done at a 'standard' frequency, possibly different from MSB tuning or redshift. ___ The calibration should be done at the MSB tuning: I am observing at or near a standard frequency. ___ The calibration should be done at the MSB tuning; If I am not close to a standard frequency, select a line-rich source which will allow for the relatively calibration the observations from night-to-night.
3) _X_ If necessary, increase the bandwidth to catch a standard line. (Increasing the bandwidth should not affect the calibration, except that the peak of very narrow lines will drop because of the lower resolution). ___ Keep the bandwidth as used in the MSB.
4) _X_ It is not essential to observe a planet. ___ Please do a continuum mode observation of a suitable planet (if available). Efficiencies derived from isolated observations of the continuum level of planets typically are not very accurate.
SpNote.title: Calibration

3) If you want more specific standard or calibration measurement you should make a separate MSBs with these measurements or include them as extra observation in your MSBs. Calibration observations should be flagged as 'calibration' on their title page to prevent unnecessary repeats.
SpNote.title: Please read

SpNote.note:
A pointing (and focus) will be done if necessary, or will be deferred if not necessary.
Normally the TSS will search for a nearby pointing source. If you have a specific pointing source in mind, insert a "Target Information" component here, and un-check the "automatic target" buttons in the Pointing and Focus eyes.
SpNote.title: Pointing and focus help

SpNote.note:
A note about notes ----------------
This is a note outlining good practice in note writing for heterodyne MSB. PLEASE replace this note with your own note or delete altogether BEFORE submitting the MSB.
Things to include in your notes -------------------------------
* Calibration details
1) Overall observing strategy for your science program. A paragraph conveying the general ideas behind your science program is useful for the observer (who may not be an expert in your field) and the TSS. (Check "show to the Observer").
2) Details of calibration observations. Spell out any specific calibrations you require in the note which is selected as "show-to-observer". Example instructions might include:
"Short sample on a nearby spectral line standard with a good CO(3-2) line e.g. OMC1".
and/or
"Short sample on a point-like planet (e.g. Uranus), with same backend set up as science target."
In short, you'll at least want something to check back-end setup and receiver performance (e.g. a spectral line standard). Optional is an efficiency measurement on a planet to check the convertion of the measured antenna temperature to an astrophysical brightness temperature. However, isolated efficiency observations scatter considerably and using a suitable average of archived values may be preferential.
3) If you want more specific standard or calibration measurement you should make a separate MSBs with these measurements or include them as extra observation in your MSBs. Calibration observations should be flagged as 'calibration' on their title page to prevent unnecessary repeats.
SpNote.title: Please read

SpNote.note: Pointing observation. Will normally be inserted as needed by TSS.
X, Y, or Z focus observation. Will normally be inserted when needed by TSS.
Pointing, focus, calibration observation. Will normally be inserted as needed by TSS.
Pointing, focus, calibration observation. Will normally be inserted as needed by TSS.
